You can also patch the app.asar file in order to force higher numbers. The point of this is to modify an Signal Desktop binary instead of needing to build from source.

I recommend bringing down resolution to 720p because of the 5 mbps sending limit for (group) screensharing.

However, this process is unofficial and you have to reapply them (from step 7 onwards) on every Signal-Desktop update in order to keep the changes. It’s also not guaranteed to work on newer versions, these steps were tested on 5.35.0-beta.1 for both Windows and Debian. There’s also always a risk of ruining the app somehow.

To protect from data loss or other risks, you can install and link to the beta version of Signal and apply these steps to the Signal Beta app, which can be used alongside the normal version of the desktop app.

Obviously the best way to do this in the end is to have a setting in the app itself to control FPS and resolution, and this is just a work around.

Individual steps

  1. Make sure Signal-Desktop is not running. Check the system tray and make sure it isn’t there.

  2. Install Node.js LTS at Node.js — Download Node.js® (don’t install the Chocolatey stuff in the Windows installer if you don’t care about Node.js)

  3. Open a terminal (bash if you have it, otherwise Powershell). If you’re on Windows, you may need to open as Administrator.

  4. Run npm install -g asar. We run this to install asar globally (so admin rights may be needed).

  5. Check that asar works: type asar and press enter and it should give usage instructions.

  6. Find the location of Signal-Desktop’s app.asar file.

    • On Linux: /opt/Signal/resources. Modifying this may require root permissions.
    • On Windows: %localappdata%\Programs\signal-desktop\resources

  7. Backup this original app.asar file in case something goes wrong.

    Also make sure again that Signal-Desktop is not running.

  8. Open a terminal in this resources folder. On Windows, you can hold SHIFT and right click a blank space and select the Open PowerShell window here option. Then unpack the app.asar file into a new directory called unpacked by running asar unpack app.asar unpacked.

  9. Open unpacked/preload.bundle.js and find the setPresenting function by searching (you can search for maxFramerate:):

      setPresenting(conversationId, hasLocalVideo, source) {
    const call = getOwn(this.callsByConversation, conversationId);
    if (!call) {
      warn("Trying to set presenting for a non-existent call");
      return;
    }
    this.videoCapturer.disable();
    if (source) {
      this.hadLocalVideoBeforePresenting = hasLocalVideo;
      this.videoCapturer.enableCaptureAndSend(call, {
        maxFramerate: 5,
        maxHeight: 1080,
        maxWidth: 1920,
        screenShareSourceId: source.id
      });
      this.setOutgoingVideo(conversationId, true);
      ...

    Change maxFramerate to 30 (or 45), maxHeight to 720, maxWidth to 1280

  10. Repack by going back to the resources directory where the app.asar is located and run asar pack unpacked app.asar. This overwrites the original app.asar. Remove the unpacked directory to save some space.

  11. Open Signal-Desktop and try to screenshare. You can create a new group with just your self and start screensharing from desktop and view the screenshare performance from your phone.

Steps 7 to 11 will need to be redone everytime there’s an update to Signal-Desktop.

"One-liner"s

This does steps 7 to 11 in one line including creation of a backup. (1280x720 at 30fps)

Pick either Bash or PowerShell options depending on what you have. These steps need to be run inside of the resources folder where the app.asar lives. You only need to run exactly one of these, not both.

  • Bash (on Windows you can also use https://gitforwindows.org or maybe WSL if you have it):

    cp app.asar "app.asar-$(date +%s).backup" && asar extract app.asar unpacked && sed -Ei -e 's/maxFramerate: [0-9]*,/maxFramerate: 30,/g' -e 's/maxHeight: [0-9]*,/maxHeight: 720,/g' -e 's/maxWidth: [0-9]*,/maxWidth: 1280,/g' unpacked/preload.bundle.js && asar pack unpacked app.asar && rm -r unpacked

  • PowerShell 7 (the default PowerShell in Windows 10 is 5.1 which is too old. download PowerShell 7 if you need it at Install PowerShell on Windows - PowerShell | Microsoft Learn)

    cp .\app.asar ".\app.asar-$([int64](Get-Date -UFormat %s)).backup" && asar extract .\app.asar .\unpacked\ && ((Get-Content .\unpacked\preload.bundle.js) -replace 'maxFramerate: [0-9]*,','maxFramerate: 30,' -replace 'maxHeight: [0-9]*,','maxHeight: 720,' -replace 'maxWidth: [0-9]*,','maxWidth: 1280,' | Out-File -encoding ascii .\unpacked\preload.bundle.js) && asar pack .\unpacked\ .\app.asar && rm -r .\unpacked\

posts.cooked:
I appreciate the effort, and I am sure someone is going to use your guide. As a temporal solution to my problem it would cut it.

But you can’t expect the normal user to do the required steps (potentially on all its devices). Once again, I don’t wish to disregard your guide (I might give it a go when I have the time). But by the nature of the issue, you can see that more people could be having the same problem.

As you have shown to me, it seems (I might be wrong) that the core root of the issue is that those values are static. I am mostly asking for an option on runtime (before the desktop is shared) that allows the user to change those values.

I can understand if smooth desktop sharing doesn’t enter the signal team’s vision, or if by the current implementation, modifying those values in runtime is not worth the trouble and developing time from both the backend and UX team. Just as it is a feature that is currently being worked on, I wanted to share an issue that most users will face. (Sound sharing its another in the same vein)

Edit: Just to add to the conversation, I suspect that Discord allows its users to select how they want to share their desktop instead doing automatically because that doesn’t always work in all cases (like giving a low bitrate to a mostly still image). Or simply they didn’t find a good enough implementation and decided to do it in that way, as gamers (their main audience) mostly know about resolutions and fps.

Javiondox:

But you can’t expect the normal user to do the required steps (potentially on all its devices).

Of course not, anything that asks the user to download developer tools and open a terminal and run commands is not user-friendly. It’s not permanent either (user has to rerun the steps when the app updates). But it works for me as a workaround to this missing feature (I use it to stream games) and I wrote the steps with enough verbosity that anyone else that really needs it at the moment can also use it at their own risk.

I will edit the guide to outline the unofficial nature.

I don’t understand it somehow: it’s clearly stated in the comment why this is so (was linked somewhere above):

    // 15fps is much nicer but takes up a lot more CPU.
    maxFramerate: 5,

i.e. you should not change this value! Unless you are interested in annoying other conversation participants.

It’s more CPU intensive for the host because of the increase in frames being captured (part of why a decent CPU is recommended for anyone getting into streaming). But the receivers just receive the frames.

I don’t personally notice or have complaints about extra CPU usage from receiver devices. Also, hopefully most devices in general don’t have excessive CPU usage when you watch a 720p video/stream in 30-60fps (plus Signal limits sending bitrate to 5 mbps)

Currently broadcasting is limited to 5fps to save bandwidth especially in group calls, but when I’m sharing my screen with my friends it’s usually to share gameplay over a wired connection. The only workaround at the moment is routing the screen through a virtual camera which would require routing system audio through a virtual line as well, I can’t imagine that’s much better for bandwidth.

I understand not increasing the default framerate but there should be a drop-down in the call settings to select a target framerate, even if it means resetting the field back to 5fps for each newly started call to reduce bandwidth usage.
